channel.title: Comments on: Journey to the Center of 1909

item.title: By: jss1954
item.dc:creator: jss1954
item.description: Thank you for a great post! About 6-7 years ago, I was browsing the panoramic maps in the LOC when I came across the Worthington Gates 1909 map of Los Angeles. I was instantly captivated by it. Here was a Los Angeles that was completely unrecognizable to me. It was a fascinating discovery! I look back now, and chancing upon that 1909 map was definitely the genesis of my present obsession with pre-WWII Los Angeles. Although the Worthington Gates is a nicer-looking map, I personally favor the Birdseye View, primarily because of its more accurate depiction of the 1909 "Million Dollar Post Office" (another little obsession of mine). It's a shame that it wasn't built up on Bunker Hill, because I'm really curious what you'd write about it!
item.content:encoded:
Thank you for a great post! About 6-7 years ago, I was browsing the panoramic maps in the LOC when I came across the Worthington Gates 1909 map of Los Angeles. I was instantly captivated by it. Here was a Los Angeles that was completely unrecognizable to me. It was a fascinating discovery! I look back now, and chancing upon that 1909 map was definitely the genesis of my present obsession with pre-WWII Los Angeles.
Although the Worthington Gates is a nicer-looking map, I personally favor the Birdseye View, primarily because of its more accurate depiction of the 1909 "Million Dollar Post Office" (another little obsession of mine). It’s a shame that it wasn’t built up on Bunker Hill, because I’m really curious what you’d write about it!
